Message.Title: Intel in 2013
Message.Msg: - Release of 7W Ivy Bridge chips making PC convertibles and PC detachables even more thinner and lighter. This will further allow the PC market to cannabalize the tablet market. - Release of mobile celeron chips adding to the breadth and variable of PC convertibles and detachables market. Soon the market will be bombarded by mobile PC devices that will blur the lines between tablets and PC - Release of Haswell the 4th generation Core will allow for average of 10+ hours of battery life for ultrabooks including convertibles and detachables. This will spur on a major refresh cycle, which many are predicting a 'pent-up' refresh. There will be a variety of Haswell including the ULV parts plus an ultra ULV parts which might come down to ~5W TDP! - Release of new Medfield SoC with integrated LTE 4G that will see Intel come into the US smartphone market for the first time. The single core Medfield has already proven to be superior to most current multi-core arm-based SoC in the market today both in terms of performance and battery life. Imagine the next version of the Medfield. There are reports that Intel will take a bigger step in 2013, by releasing the Bay Trail Medfield with quad-core developed on the most state of the art 22nm process! There are rumors flying around now that an Intel SoC will power the secret XPhone being developed by the Google's Motorola. The phone is said to have some innovations never before seen in a phone including flexible touch screens. - Intel will further maximize profits by doing foundry work on the side. Cisco and Apple are rumored to be future customers. In terms of Apple, the rumor is that Intel will not only be foundry for Apple but that future iPads will have Intel inside! Revenue are predicted to increase by $7 billion from these two foundry customers alone ($2 billion for Cisco and $5 billion for Apple)

Intel has competition like it has never seen before. As long as ARMH makes good products and makes money they can keep pressuring Intel. You ain't seen nothing yet, ARMH is very aggressive and getting into every flippin thing a chip can go in.

competition? the best arm chips doesn't have 64-bit yet and can't even compare with Intel's products from 6 years ago? you call that competition? Intel just took out AMD now they have their guns on arm...ya, you are right about one thing...you ain't seen nothing yet.

Message.Title: I just got a Samsung ATIV Smart PC!!!
Message.Msg: I went to the Microsoft store earlier today to check out some of the PC convertibles and PC detachables. The Samsung ATIV Smart PC caught my eye and I was playing with it and the girl there started showing me some of the tricks to use with Windows 8. She told me that, for the holiday season, I can buy and try it for 30 days and if I don't like I can return it. I said what the heck, sure! I've been playing with it for 3 hours now and I gotta tell you, it is pure joy. I don't know why there is such negativity regarding windows 8. To me it is amazing. The way you can flip thru the different apps you are using; the way you can have 2 windows on the same screen and still have backgroud apps like music playing in the background. Did you know there is a app called Music Tube that allows you to listen to your favorite songs and artist and watch their videos from youtube? You don't even need to buy any music! it is amazing. But the best feature with the Samsung ATIV Smart PC is it's a PC and tablet in one. I was playing with it on the couch and then I wanted to write an email and without missing a beat i went to my table which had the keyboard dock; i just placed the tablet half on it and started typing my email. Now that is cool! And then there is the Desktop ie. PC app that allows you to do everything you would normally do in windows 7. I don't have office installed on it yet, but I will just need to get a cheap USB portable CD/DVD drive to install all my software. I am tell you straight now. If you are long INTC...hold on to your shares. I am more convinced than ever that PCs will be making a come back in a big way. PC convertibles and PC detachables such as the Samsung ATIV Smart PC will eat away at the current tablets. They will dominant the tablet market in similar fashion as how Android took over the smartphone market. Intel is in the best position here because the only way to fully benefit from Windows 8 (with its touch capabilities) is to upgrade your hardware. And when people decide to upgrade their hardware, they are going to pick a Intel-based device because they want to be able use the same Windows program they have been using in Windows 7. The iPad can't give you this; android can't give you this; Windows RT can't give you this. Only a Windows 8 device running on Intel can!
Medfield Atoms already blew away Tegra 3 and is competitive with Samsung's ARM. Next iteration would be even better.

Topic.Title: 100 PFLOPS of Ivy Bridge EP and Intel PHI supercomputer power.

Message.Msg: "Yeah... what makes his assumptions incorrect..." I would like to read more from his source documents but I have not found much data available. One assumption that I know is wrong is his $2,500 E5, v2 estimated pricing. Anyone with a 100,000 part E5 v2 and 100,000 part Phi order will not pay anything near the 5,000 part tray price. Theo gave a pessimistic evaluation using 5,000 unit pricing and then made a guess at the manufacturing cost. Theo's assumptions was: "a Xeon E5-2567W v2should set you back (note: this is a future part, pricing was an estimate based on current line-up) for $2,500" How many cores, MB of cache, frequency do you think the E5-2567W, v2 will have? I think the computation model will be to operate primarily on the PHI and the E5, v2 will be needed to stream chunks of data to them. Streaming data to the Phi will not likely benefit from a large cache. The data will be read from a disk, transferred to the Phi and little E5 processing. They would use the streaming IO buffers to transfer data which bypass the cache. Adding capative loading to the bus quickly slows it down because the CPU memory buffers cannot drive the extra load at the same frequency. Your desktop machine will run faster if you have fewer DIMMs for the same reason. If you have 8GB of memory in a machine, it will run slower if you have 4 x 2GB DIMMs versus 2 x 4GB all operating at the same frequency. "Free is always below cost..." Even Theo estimates that $50,000,000 of the $100,000,000 contract will be going to Intel. That is not free. He also suggests that there is a service contract that goes along. Not free. Of course, you already knew that too. "YOu already knew that's not what I'm referring to..." YEs. I thought I knew BUt I WAs HOping I WAs WRong. You are quite rational when you are in discussion mode. I have read the first 100 pages of the 500 page EU report. I should go back and try to read it again. The first 100 pages were only about why the EU was justified in denying Intel a 6-month postponement and instead just issuing their findings without any Intel input. IMO, that was wrong and when results the July 8th EU appeals court are released, we will know a little more. I will discuss lawsuit with you if you really want but in a LAwsuit THread.

Intel has been trying to get down to the power envelope of mobile for about 6 years now. Medfield is the first version of their chip that borderline fits. Their vantage point, therefore, continues to be the high power end. From there, its easy to speculate that getting your power consumption into a budget is simply a matter of optimizing from amongst a range of performance options that you've already developed. In other words a very tenable task. But if you look at their results from performing this very optimization over the last 6 years, they are depressing. It leads me to believe they don't know what they're talking about because they've never been there. ARM on the other hand has gone way lower than the mobile phone battery operating point. e.g. Their M0+ which is used in embedded. Secondly, if you look at design trends amongst computing gadget makers such as Apple, they are moving away from performance driven improvement to a more use-centric approach. This greatly favors the low end of the power spectrum because with advances in process technology, the low end is going to become more and more performant until it is good enough for most applications. No-one can tell the difference between a game running at 30 fps and 130 fps because after a certain speed, you can't tell the difference. The high end, Intel's vantage point, therefore gets relegated to niche uses such as super-computers.

Message.Title: Happy New Year from the Semiconductor Wikipedia Project!
Message.Msg: It was an amazing year for SemiWiki and I would like to thank all who participated. SemiWiki traffic doubled again last year which is amazing in itself. SemiWiki membership more than tripled as we continue to add vertical markets (EDA, IP, Services, Foundry). More people are blogging on SemiWiki and the Forums and Wikis are coming to life. With millions of page views I can comfortably say that social media is now an integral part of the fabless semiconductor ecosystem. What’s in store for SemiWiki in the new year? We will continue to grow with more original content, another vertical market (FPGA), and increased exposure through a new partnership with Yahoo and other mainstream news sources. Today more than 450,000 people are reading SemiWiki. In 2013 that number will exceed 1,000,000, believe it. I hope to see you there!

Topic.Title: I just got a Samsung ATIV Smart PC!!!

Message.Msg: Lingering on the desktop a moment, you can also forget gaming, too: though the Smart PC should technically run many legacy x86 games, its integrated Intel Graphics Media Accelerator yields a 3DMark06 score of just 374. In the disk benchmark ATTO, meanwhile, its read and write speeds topped out at just 82 MB/s and 36 MB/s, respectively. We'll venture to say we don't expect much better of other Atom-powered tablets; if anything, the buggy performance is the bigger crime here. Still, as we go through the list of possible use cases for this thing, it's worrisome that we have to cross mundane tablet tasks and desktop productivity off the list. If the Smart PC offers unreliable performance in tablet mode and is too sluggish to get much done in desktop mode, why might you spend $700 on a device like this?

"Medfield Atoms already blew away Tegra 3 and is competitive with Samsung's ARM. Next iteration would be even better." Tegra 3 is 40nm versus Medfield at 32nm? I wonder why Google chose Tegra 3 for their tablets instead of Medfield? Lets see how Medfield does against Tegra 4 on 28nm. My guess is that it won't even be close. Tegra 4 is a screamer.

I think you arm fans are missing the point of what Matt is saying. Once the process gets to 14nm and below, arm will not be competing with Atom, it will be competing with Intel's Core processors because the power envelop will be equal at that point. I believe Intel's strategy has always been to move the core down into the Atom's power envelop...once we get to 14nm, Atom will be the low end SoC while the high-end SoCs will be running Broadwell. arm's job is alot tougher, they have to improve performance while still maintain the power envelop and they are 4 generations behind. In terms of the "good enough" argument, well 1) prices go up you build higher performing processors and processes 2) Given the choice, I would pick a faster processor over "good enough" anyday

Just to clarify, Intel does not have to modify anything with the Core processors to get it to the same power envelop as the Atom's...Once it gets to 14nm, the PROCESS itself will take care of it. They are modifying Atom now as a Low-end architecture...onces the two meet, at 14nm...they will be basically the same....but Core will be high-end while Atom low-end. This is why are you hearing rumors that Broadwell might not have sockets and will be BGP only.

Oh... "I believe Intel's strategy has always been to move the core down into the Atom's power envelop." ARM's success is partly due to that was exactly NOT INtel's strategy... "In terms of the "good enough" argument, well 1) prices go up you build higher performing processors and processes 2) Given the choice, I would pick a faster processor over "good enough" anyday" Do you use the i7 Extreme ?? Or is your CPU good enough...

Message.Title: An article on Google Finance for Intel, trashing Cramer's call.
Message.Msg: Here's a part of the article. I tend to believe that Cramer knows little about Mellanox, and as a television commentator, he creates unfound drama. Four years ago, I watched him "hang" then-SanDisk Corporation (Nasdaq:SNDK) CEO Dr. Eli Harari on the wall of shame in his weird studio, because Harari would not agree to sell SanDisk to Samsung at $26 per share, after which SanDisk crashed to $5 per share. But I did not see Cramer apologize when SanDisk's share recovered to $50 while Harari was still CEO.
Intel is plagued by over-commitment and under-delivery. They do need a management shake-up.

Message.Title: Acer to release $99 tablet in emerging markets.
Message.Msg: Now that just about everyone and their brother is selling tablets, the inevitable price wars will begin. Acer is off to an early start, according a report in the Wall Street Journal. The WSJ is reporting that Acer is planning to launch the Iconia B1 Android tablet for just $99, a major price cut compared to 7-inch tablets like the $159 Amazon Kindle Fire. Unfortunately for U.S. consumers, the company is currently planning on releasing the Iconia B1 in emerging markets, though it has submitted the tablet to the FCC. The launch is designed to combat Asus' rumored low-price Android slate, which is supposedly also due next year, though an Asus spokesperson denied such reports. The new budget tablet for developing economies marks a pivot for Acer in its tablet strategy. According to the Journal's unnamed source, the company is shifting from higher-profit devices as competitors like the Google Nexus 10 drag prices down. Acer's push for cheaper tablets isn't limited to the Iconia B1. Another source told the Journal that the company is developing a new Intel-based Windows 8 tablet as its current versions are "too pricey." These include the Iconia W510, which is selling for $549 and up, and the Iconia W700, which starts at $800. Even if the Iconia B1 never reaches American shores, the day when a major manufacturer releases a $99 tablet in the United States will soon be upon us. There are too many players in the market, and someone will be desparate enough to take the plunge in order to move units. Maybe it will be Acer after all, or another Android proponent like Lenovo. Or maybe Amazon will finally take the leap, and drop the Kindle Fire to an ad-supported $100.

Message.Title: Intel is gonna hurt Qualcom bad..........real bad
Message.Msg: Although the tweet didn’t mention specifically any launch delays, it said that Qualcomm is having problems meeting the demand for its highly sought-after Snapdragon S4 processor, which spells trouble for Asus, since it’s the same processor that powers the Asus Padfone. The Verge got in touch with an Asus spokesperson who confirmed the processor shortage that is “affecting all of Qualcomm’s customers”. Note, however, that a delay was not mentioned. So, how bad is this S4 chip shortage? Well, bad enough to warrant public declarations from Qualcomm’s top brass. CEO Paul Jacobs declared last week that the American chip-maker is facing problems with satisfying the big demand for the 28nm process chip. The shortage will supposedly not affect Qualcomm’s top-tier clients, such as Samsung, but is likely to perturb smaller clients, like Asus.

Topic.Title: Intel is gonna hurt Qualcom bad..........real bad

Message.Msg: How many of Qualcom's customers will decide that working with Intel and a better or even equal chip makes much more sense than working with Qualcom at a later node that they can't even supply consistently? The tide is about to change in Mobile and WORST CASE, Intel will get a share of the pie that makes it's Mobile endeavors fruitful.

Topic.Title: Acer to release $99 tablet in emerging markets.

Message.Msg: A tablet for emerging markets should feature desktop applications and not assume a WiFi connection. So this is probably a tablet for people in emerging-market cities. But the idea of an affordable computer for third-world rural-areas is a computer that should have a keyboard. Then letters or documents can be typed and such. A tablet is best used as a coffee-shop browser.
